text: in the 13 years that I've been at
Comcast we've seen it evolve from a
cable company into a software
development company and our players and
our teammates are actually looking for
better technologies to use to solve the
problems that were previously impossible
but using serverless and AWS
technologies we're able to solve those
problems a lot of times we spend much of
our time talking about the technology of
serverless we talk about the speed and
the performance and the scale
capabilities in the end that's obviously
a big piece of the puzzle but we found a
Comcast are two other pieces that are
really important to us that of the
finance or value side of it as well as
the organization and the team
specifically when there's tight
timelines when there's other constraints
in terms of team sizes or budgetary
capabilities the service is the only way
to approach the problem from an
organization perspective we actually
find that the a players the people we
want to be investing in are it's already
seeking out service as a way to approach
hard and maybe even previously
impossible problems because they're
really the ones that are worth solving
with new technologies and these are our
best talented engineers are the ones
that want to solve those problems and
all we have to do is empower them with
technologies like service and make sure
they're accountable for the results and
the rest of sort of his history so in
2016 Comcast and Netflix announced a
partnership to provide a Netflix
application on the set-top box and this
was an integrated experience and we did
it in four months this was something
that we could not have done without
using serviced many of the things that
we do for our customers are things that
couldn't be done without serverless
technologies I often find that the AWS
approach but asking customers what they
want is aligning very nicely with the
way the Comcast wants to approach our
own customers
